intro: Eriocoma parishii, commonly known as the Parry's ericoid, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in mountainous regions. It has a low-growing, mat-forming habit and produces tiny, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in the spring. Eriocoma parishii is often found in alpine and subalpine environments, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions.
